reviewText: After waiting patiently for many years, THE BIONIC WOMAN (1976) has finally come to DVD! I watched this show as a kid and loved it along withThe Six Million Dollar Man The Complete Seriesand its temporary replacementWonder Woman: The Complete First Season.I finally had the time to finish watching all of the DVDs in this SEASON ONE set and I loved every single minute of it! Not only do you get all the crossover episodes from "The Six Million Dollar Man," which introduced Jaime Sommers, but you also get the follow-up episode that brought her back to life after she died on TSMDM, or so we thought (I always wondered about that, hahaha) and the pilot episodes for BW.I used to sit glued to the TV set when THE BIONIC WOMAN came on and I must say that I'm still impressed as an adult viewer. I'm amazed at the production value that went into this series from the special effects, to the actual shots of actress Lindsay Wagner (Jamie Sommers) or Richard Anderson (Oscar Goldman) landing in a helicopter. Even Wagner's stunt double looked like her from a distance, whereas Lynda Carter's double on "Wonder Woman" looked rather man-ish at times.The series looks nice and sharp and the story lines are intriguing. There's a "play all" feature or you can play by episode selection. I really enjoyed "Mirror Image," which introduced the character "Lisa Galloway," who got plastic surgery to look like Sommers, to infiltrate the OSI (Wagner in a dual role). The scenes from this episode remained fresh in my mind after all these years along with the line, "I might have yo' looks Jaime Sommers, but I sho' don't have yo' moves!" I also enjoyed "Ghost Hunter," which follows "Mirror Image" on DVD 4, because it also stands out in my mind, and has a young Kristy MacNichol as a guest star.Anyway, the extras on this set include:=====  EXTRAS  =====* Gag Reel - 01:41-minutesBehind-the-scenes footage of the actors flubbing line or laughing etc.* "Bionic Beginnings" - 24:27-minutesPresent day featurette that discusses how the show got off the ground, how filming was done, and why it became such an iconic hit. Those taking part in the interviews include Lindsay Wagner (Jamie Sommers), Richard Anderson (Oscar Goldman), Kenneth Johnson (Creator/director/writer), Martin E. Brooks (Dr. Rudy Wells), James D. Parriott (Writer), Alan J. Levi, Jerry London (BW Directors), Inge Rosenberg (Wagner's stunt double), Robbie Rist (Andrew - AKA "Oliver" on the Brady Bunch) and Janice Whitby (Katy Fembot).The featurette was very informative and it was great seeing some of the lesser known actors who had memorable performances on BW particularly Robbie Rist, who played Jamie Sommers's student "Andrew" in the first few episodes and Janice Whitby who played the "Katy Fembot." I don't remember if Whitby had any lines, she doesn't make an appearance until the second season, but she had such an impact on me as a kid! Maybe she was the first fembot who got her face mask ripped off and you saw she was a robot or it was the serene, robotic, beautiful expression that lacked any kind of emotion on her face, but whatever it was, it scared the crap out of me so much so that her image stayed with me throughout the years. When I saw her pop up on this featurette, I knew exactly who it was! Too bad Jennifer Darling (Peggy Callahan) wasn't part of this featurette, because she's the only one missing next to Lee Majors. Maybe the studio is saving those interviews for upcoming season releases?I can barely wait for seasons 2 & 3 of THE BIONIC WOMAN to be released! I want to see the Fembots, and the sentient defense system named "Alex" that tried to stop Jaime in "Dooomsday Is Tomorrow pt.2." Not to mention the return of "Lisa Galloway" in "Deadly Ringer 1 & 2." Oh boy, do I need a life!Trivia: This is probably an urban legend but I heard that the TV series "Wonder Woman" was done as a temporary replacement for ABC's "The Bionic Woman" after Lindsay Wagner was injured in a car accident and had to stop production on BW, and ABC wanted another female hero type show to fill the spot.
summary: I'm *Ready* For *Seasons 2 & 3; Bring On The *Fembots* Already!

reviewText: Okay, rather than reading everyones reviews about the disk set and added commentary I will set the record straight once and for all.This 4 disk set claims it has 5 crossover episodes of the Six Million Dollar Man. Truth be told, there are only 4. The Bionic Woman (2 part version, I'll discuss the controversy over this later)The Return of the Bionic Woman ( 2 parts) and Welcome Home, Jaime Part 1.  Welcome Home, Jaime Part 1 never aired as a SMDM episode, it was supposed to, but about a week or so before airing, it was decided to go ahead an air it as the BW pilot. It did feature Lee Majors (in part 1 only I believe) but if they are considering that a SMDM crossover, then the episode "Deadly Missles" should have also been included as Lee Majors is in that episode as well. (making a total of 6)  Some will say that the credits were redone for BW for syndication, studio sources said, there was never a SMDM episode aired with the SMDM style opening or credits of SMDM.  There are a few websites that list conflicting airdates for the episodes as well.  The episode guide that places the two episodes 4 days from eachother is incorrect. The correct airdates are January 14 and 21, 1976. Part 1 is included in some episode guides of SMDM because it was originally going to air as a SMDM.Secondly, The Bionic Woman episode of SMDM has been divided into 2 parts on the disk set. There are episode guides that show that it was aired in 2 parts and others that state it aired as a single 2 hour episode on its first run. The UK version of season 1 and the lone VHS tape released in the mid 80s, show it as a single 2 hour run.  There are several other SMDM episodes that did this as well (Thunderbird Connection, Bionic Boy, The Lost Island) So it will be interesting to see how they are packaged on Time-Life's complete set next month.The video and sound quality of these disks surpass even the Digitally Mastered UK sets released some time ago. On correction though. The use of the term AC-3 suggests dolby digital 5.1 which is not the case, its DD 2.0 standard, and the TV epsisodes are not in Widescreen as advertised. Why would they be, in 1970s TV shows were made to fit the TV Screen.Can't wait for Season 2. No announcement yet but sometime next year all 3 seasons are supposed to be available.  Ironically, there were no crossovers in Season 3 as it was airing on NBC, whereas SMDM still aired on ABC.
summary: The Bionic Woman has arrived and their are a few misleading facts....

reviewText: Writer Kenneth Johnson was assigned to create a girlfriend for "The Six Million Dollar Man" Steve Austin (Lee Majors) and then, just as suddenly, kill her off. Obviously, the talent and allure of Lindsay Wagner as Jaimie Sommers proved too strong. After receiving tons of letters from upset fans, ABC Network reversed its initial decision and ordered Johnson to bring Jaimie back to life immediately. Only in TV Land could Jaimie be brought back to life after being placed in "suspended animation." Soon, ABC had a Bionic franchaise. By January, 1976, Jaimie had her own series. Wanting to repay the U.S. government for her miraculous Bionic rebuild, Jaimie is anxious to go to work for OSI:  the Office of Scientific Investigation." After getting a "cover job" as a  school teacher at the Ventura Air Force Base, Jaimie moves in to a small house owned by Steve Austin's adoptive parents (Martha Scott and Ford Rainey). There were several cross-over episodes between "Man" and "Woman"; as well as actors Richard Anderson and Martin E. Brooks doing double-duty as Oscar Goldman and Dr. Rudy Welles on both series. One burning question remains: With the OSI sending Jaimie on so many top secret missions, how did she ever find time to grade her students' classroom assignments?Lindsay Wagner herself was the key to "The Bionic Woman's" success. Wagner's performance is all the more extraordinary considering how outlandish the storylines are. The series holds up amazingly well, while the weekly plots do not. Yet, Lindsay brings a central warmth, believeability, and  intelligence to Jaimie that somehow makes the entire series work. Lindsay/Jaimie is the perfect combination of beauty, bionics, and, most importantly, brains. The best Season One episode episode, "Mirror Image" has Lindsay playing two roles. In addition to Jaimie, she also portrays Lisa Galloway, a Southern woman  (recruited by an evil doctor and associates, of course) who undergoes plastic surgery to become an (almost) exact double of Jaimie. With Jaimie on vacation and too quickly presumed dead, Lisa takes her place and attempts to kill OSI boss Oscar Goldman. I already have "Bionic Woman: Season 2" on Pre-order.  Lisa Galloway returns in the Season 2 two part story "Deadly Ringer." Season 2 also features Jaimie's classic battle with the evil Fembots. I can't wait!Just put logic aside, and enjoy "The Bionic Woman" for what it always was: good escapist sci-fi/fantasy,  occasionally campy, fun.
summary: "THE PERFECT COMBINATION OF BEAUTY, BIONICS, AND BRAINS"

reviewText: Having grown up in the era during this time when television was at its peak and science-fiction was in its development stages, all I can say is, "my God!  What an amazing journey from then to now!"  These were the shows that pioneered sci-fi and why this phenominon is what it is today.  What started as ABC network's very first 2-part episode, resulted as one of television's leading female iconic sci-fi characters (right along with Lynda Carter and JoAnna Cameron) the 70's proved that women weren't just household figures, but kick-ass characters and inspirational role models for girls and women everywhere.  From the first episode of The Bionic Woman on the 2nd season of The Six Million Dollar Man, Lindsay Wagner was a sensation.  Her role as Jaime Sommers left America wanting more, even after her apparent death, and the networks listened by bringing Jaime back to us and to Steve.  And what a revival it was in The Return of The Bionic Woman parts 1 & 2.  Season 1 takes you to post her return and gives her character a life of her very own, once again capturing the very essence of the Bionic Woman.  This is the story of Jaime Sommers and her own personal evolution from tennis pro to school teacher/OSI agent while living again with her new life and limbs, courtesy of the US Government, Oscar Goldman and Dr. Rudy Wells.  She at times struggles with her cyborg abilities, but reminds herself that she's also a woman, holding on to her human half, capable of love and emotions.  Jaime Sommers captured the hearts of characters in her adventures and America's viewers every week for 3 unforgetable seasons from 1976-1978.  This was a role that Lindsay was meant to portray, and we can also give thanks to Lindsay's sister to her encouragement.  What a great way to capture the beginning of 3 great DVD boxed sets no bionic fan should be without.  This show, like its male counterpart, was definitely ahead of its time with not only it's subject of bionics,  but the inspiration the term had to the medical and science world making science fiction a reality.  Enjoy these classics that can be shared for generations to follow and conventions to come.

reviewText: The Bionic Woman was not intended as a spinoff series. Originally a two-part episode of The Six Million Dollar Man, the love story that introduced Jaime Sommers (and ended in her death) was such a ratings and fan hit that the character was resurrected for another two-parter before being given a series of her own.  As a child, I watched both series, but quickly became more enthusiastic about The Bionic Woman.  I was entertained by Steve Austin's derring-do, but I cared about Jaime.Much of the success of TBW must be credited to Lindsay Wagner.  She brings a combination of charm and intelligence unseen on television since Elizabeth Montgomery's turn in Bewitched - adding hints of sadness and vulnerability. Richard Anderson, also, brings a fatherly quality to Oscar Goldman - a contrast with his more hard-nosed portrayal in The Six Million Dollar Man.  These qualities were utterly lacking in the unmemorable and mercifully short lived 2007 remake.There are a few snippets of dialogue I would not have understood when the series first aired: It's obvious that "the Secretary" Oscar often refers to is Henry Kissinger; In an episode that takes place in an unnamed Middle-Eastern country, Oscar wryly comments that he's traveling under an assumed name because his last name would be unpopular there.An array of distinguished guest stars can be seen in Season One, from Andy Griffith to Tippi Hedrin.  The visual style is in keeping with the Universal Television look of the 1970s: simple camera setups, with establishing shots transitioning to two-shots and close-ups, and very little camera movement beyond the occasional pan or zoom.  After the "Blair Witch" style constant motion of today's series, this simplicity is a welcome relief.The film elements look reasonably clean - light grain and scratches are visible at times.  During the slow motion effects sequences, there is some jumpiness in the image, which I don't remember seeing during the original airing (but that was a long time ago and TV screens were a lot smaller then).  One consistent problem is that the fade outs before commercial breaks seem to have been altered, so there is a distracting cut-off effect. The sound is two channel mono.The bonus features include a documentary, very brief blooper reel, and episode commentary.Despite the quibbles with the transfer, I am giving this set 5 stars.  I look forward to the release of Seasons Two and Three, and hopefully the reunion movies.
summary: A Welcome Reunion with Old Friends

reviewText: Perhaps it simply boils down to having been a boy growing-up in the late 70's that has brought on various nostalgic moments for me upon first hearing that The Bionic Woman: Season One was being released on DVD.Ah, the seventies: a time filled with afro perms, polyester bell bottom pants large enough to park a Ford Gran Torino (no offense Starsky & Hutch!) in, the suspicious pet rock phenomenon, oil embargos that had clunkers lined up for blocks and helping to put current events in their proper perspective was Super Grouch Archie Bunker! And, then came running (literally!) a stunning actress named Lindsey Wagner as the Bionic Woman and everything changed. Well, sort of.Marking her first appearance on the successful TV series The Six Million Dollar Man (starring Lee Majors) the BW was only to last two episodes. Studios executives did not have the acute vision that her creator Kenneth Johnson possessed and despite his pleas to allow her character to survive, she was "killed" off and thought to never be heard from again. But, after her surprised success on the SMDM and given the public outcry condemning her early "death", studio executives found themselves begging Johnson and Wagner back for not just another episode or two, but they wanted her to star in her own spinoff series! Johnson and Wagner were more than up for the challenge and, thus, the BW was reborn.By today's technological standards, the BW's special effects are elementary. However, necessity required creative invention and the crew managed to bring the illusions from dream to reality every week with fascinating and moderately believable results. Albeit, some episodes faired better than others in this realm and for all the effects that didn't come off entirely as intended, the main focus always remained on the characters and the dilemmas they were facing. The bottom line in storytelling still holds true: you can have all the spectacular special effects you could ever want, but if the story isn't worth a damn than the whole concept ends up being much to do about nothing.The first season is a mix and match of the subpar and the truly entertaining. As with any new series, most of the first season is about finding its roots; finding its legs and learning how to use them. The initial impression is that the writers wanted to shoot Jaime into the stratosphere; to make her a force to be reckoned with! They were partly successful. There is a constant `vibe' that the BW had to first be proven as a non-threatening entity to viewers. Especially for those viewers just out of training pants!Necessary? Not really.When not using her super-mechanical skills to clean her kitchen floor, or to whip up a pie in mere seconds or compete in a beauty pageant, the skills of the BW are shown to minimal effect in the first season. However, here are a few episodes that excel at demonstrating her bionic abilities: The Bionic Woman, Part 2, Welcome Home Jaime, Part 2, The Deadly Missiles, and The Jailing of Jaime, to name a few), but most seem to keep her `tamed down'. However, more bionic action is to ensue in following seasons.Given a budget of $400,000 an episode and filmed on a breathless 6-day shooting schedule (which was later bumped up to 7 days to allow Ms. Wagner a chance for some much needed rest) and on 35mm film, the series was a non-stop action-packed producing machine. Ratings soared for both BW and SMDM series' and their demise seemed to be an afterthought. However, time and technology moves on and while most of the episodes were fun and entertaining, they also began to show their age in a time when the medium itself was about to make some serious technological advances. In retrospect, the first season of the BW comes off as too "gimmicky" and too "family-friendly." Something moms the world over may have been pleased with, but that did not bid well with action-deprived males, as well as with younger audiences who's expectations where rising with each episode. But, viewers were in this for the long haul and Jaime Sommer's would manage to wiggle her way into viewers' hearts for years time to come.Video: shot in the standard 1.33:1 aspect ratio and on 35mm film with color done by Technicolor, episodes reflect the economic `Universal' lighting method (keep everything brightly lit so as to reduce the amount of setups, thus ultra-efficient!) thus, the series lacks a unique and dramatic composition. In other words, this series is hard-pressed to help show off your High Def TV. However, this DVD release is sure to be the best the series will ever look. So, enjoy it for what it is and for not what it isn't!Audio: English Dolby Digital 2.0.  Audio is often `thin' sounding, but adequately delivers dialogue. Again, age of the show rears its ugly head here. The mix is purely conventional and will do nothing to show off your high-end surround setup.Bonus Content: things get a better here as there are several informative commentary tracks done by various writers and directors. Kenneth Johnson, BW creator, is by far the most entertaining of the bunch and it is highly recommended that you keep a pen and paper readily available to jot down notes, as Mr. Johnson presents some valuable words of wisdom to anyone trying to get into The Biz.Summing up the remaining extras is a gag reel, photo gallery and a recently produced Bionic Beginnings featurette showcasing interviews with various cast and crew that are still fortunate enough to be around talk about their personal experiences on the show.Parting thoughts:  if you want to revisit the 70's era of TV, back to when it was all about the story and not just the glamour and want some good clean, good guy vs. bad guy [...] action along the way, the Bionic Woman is an excellent choice!
summary: 'Bionic' Babe busts both heads and hearts!

reviewText: Ever since the advent of digital video discs consumers and fans of classic television shows have been hoping and demanding to see "The Bionic Woman" on DVD. The series that starred Lindsay Wagner and made her into a household name was released in Europe on Region 2 dics, but the North American marketplace was virtually ignored due to ownership issues. Now, this wonderful and innovative series about a woman who possesses bionics and works undercover for the OSI while being a school teacher by day, comes to DVD on October 19, 2010. I for one am a very happy boy! I grew up watching Lindsay Wagner fight the bad guys and would watch with anxiety week after week to see what adventures the bionic woman would get herself embroiled in."The Bionic Woman" got her start on a two-part "Six Million Dollar Man". At the end of the second episode Jamie Sommers actually died. Overnight ABC was inundated with letters demanding Jamie live and be given her own series. Fred Silverman, president of the network and keen on seeing potential Nielsen ratings, especially those of a young demographic, caved in and Jamie Sommers was brought back to life and given her own weekly show, sometimes garnering higher ratings than that of Lee Major's series ("The Bionic Woman" finished at #5 in the 1975-1976 Nielsen Ratings)."The Bionic Woman" was pure comic book fluff with a strong, intelligent woman as the lead, but the series would have been a bomb if not for the excellent acting chomps of Lindsay Wagner. Wagner was very likeable in her portrayal which explains why any girl watching "The Bionic Woman" during its original run wanted to be her and the boys wanted to marry her. Lindsay Wagner even won an Emmy for Outstanding Performance by a Lead Actress in a Drama Series in 1977. This was no small feat as Lindsay's competition that year was Angie Dickinson for "Police Woman", Kate Jackson ("Charlie's Angels"), Sada Thompson ("Family"), and Michael Learned for "The Waltons".This oustanding four disc DVD box set will feature all 13 season one episodes that began airing in January, 1976 (the show was a midseason replacement) along with a slew of bonus features. The bonuses include a brand new featurette with Lindsay Wagner being interviewed called "Bionic Beginnings", audio commentary from Kenneth Johnson who created and directed the series, a gag reel (this is not to be missed as the bloopers are hilarious and Lindsay proves she has a tongue like a sailor!), and photo gallery. To make things even more appealing this set will feature two crossover episodes from "The Six Million Dollar Man" that showed how Jamie Sommers came to be. These episodes are entitled "The Bionic Woman-Part 1" (aired March 16, 1975) and "Part 2" (March 23, 1975), "The Return of The Bionic Woman-Part 1" (September 14, 1975) and "Part 2" (September 21, 1975)".Important to note too is that it has been long thought by fans and critics of "The Bionic Woman" that the episode entitled "Welcome Home Jamie Part 1" was first aired on ABC as a "Six Million Dollar Man" episode. The truth is that is not the case. Recently in October, 2010 research consultants from Timelife who are bringing the entire "Six Million Dollar Man" series to DVD have discovered that "Welcome Home Jamie Part 1" was indeed the first ever "Bionic Woman" episode to be telecast on network television. reviewText: Toward the end of its second season, the producers of the ABC sci-fi hit "The Six Million Dollar Man" detected a disturbing trend: its Nielson numbers were slipping!  I believe the core audience of tween boys had remained loyal, but the network must have realized that they'd need more going forward if they wanted to make prime time money on the program.  Creator Ken Johnson then got a bright idea: how about doing a "Bride of Frankenstien" episode?  Some mothers and sisters might even tune in!  So the studio -- Universal -- got it done, making what would turn out to be a truly inspired casting choice, making what they thought would be their last use of a hitherto little-known young woman they had under contract: Lindsay Wagner.In the episode, Steve Austin returned to his hometown of Ojai, California where he ran into old flame Jaime Sommers, a school-days sweetheart turned tennis pro.  Smitten all over again, Steve literally sweeps Jaime several thousand feet *OFF* her feet, taking her skydiving to celebrate a hastily-agreed-to engagement.  When her parachute snags in the trees on the way down, Jaime is nearly killed, leaving Steve just one option: approach his boss, Oscar Goldman (Richard Anderson) with a request only he can make: outfit Jaime with bionics to save her life!  Oscar does so out of consideration for Steve, and Jaime then offers her services as Steve's helper in a raid on the mansion of a crooked industrialist.  Unbeknownst to anyone else, Jaime has been having problems with her bionics, which her body is rejecting!  She goes on the outing with Steve, but the assault fails, and Steve gets her to the top secret government hospital where the man who outfitted them both -- Dr. Rudy Wells (Martin E. Brooks) tries, but fails to save Jaime's life.  After all, the actress was no longer under contract, and anyway, how could a MARRIED bionic secret agent go on world-saving missions?Of course we know now that Universal and ABC made perhaps their costliest ever mistake by killing off Jaime.  Literally thousands of letters poured into network headquarters -- not just from young fans, but even from some of the adults in their lives as well, castigating "The Black Tower" for offering up a positive female role model, then doing her in so the strong man in her life could continue unencoumbered.  Over the summer, this issue stopped being about ratings and became one of PR rehabbing for the studio and network: they simply HAD TO resolve this somehow!So the third season of "Sil Mil" started with ANOTHER Bionic Woman two-parter, at the end of which Jaime was shown heading back home to California to become a schoolteacher, since she obvously couldn't play tennis anymore, having "tuned down" limbs in no condition to beat Billy Jean King, or anybody else.  After all, Lindsay Wagner really wanted to find movie roles.  The whole idea of a science fiction TV series initially did not appeal to her at all.America wouldn't let her back out, though, so in January, 1976 a second program based on the bionic cyborg premise hit the airwaves, leaving ABC in the weird spot of competing with itself, and the supporting cast having to work two shows at once.  In this DVD release of the first season of ABC's *ORIGINAL* Bionic Woman, expderience once again the classic from its origins (detailed above) to the first baker's dozen stories in which America's first non-cartoon-derived female superhero puts crime in its place while being just as respectful to the criminals as she is to her friends (she was an only child whose parents were killed in a car crash several years earlier), family, boss and colleagues.  With several much-anticipated extras including cast interviews, an episode-length commentary by creator Ken Johnson and more, it's *FINALLY* time to relive this never-topped gem of late 20th Century TV entertainment.
